overview: Iron is an essential trace mineral required for oxygen transport, energy production, DNA synthesis and numerous metabolic processes. Most iron in the body is found in hemoglobin in red blood cells, where it binds oxygen for delivery to tissues. It is also present in myoglobin in muscle and in iron-dependent enzymes involved in oxidative metabolism and immune function.
benefits: Supports formation of hemoglobin, enabling oxygen transport throughout the body
Essential for myoglobin in muscle cells, supporting oxygen storage and muscle performance
Required for energy production through involvement in mitochondrial electron transport
Contributes to normal cognitive development and function
Important for immune system activity and resistance to infection
Supports normal growth and development, especially during infancy, childhood and pregnancy
sideEffects: Excessive iron intake from supplements can cause gastrointestinal distress such as nausea, constipation and abdominal pain
Very high intakes can lead to acute toxicity, especially in children, with symptoms including vomiting, diarrhea and organ damage
Chronic high iron stores (e.g., in hereditary hemochromatosis or repeated high-dose supplementation) can cause liver damage, heart problems and endocrine dysfunction
Iron supplements can interact with certain medications, including some antibiotics and thyroid medications
deficiencySigns: Iron-deficiency anemia, characterized by fatigue, weakness, pale skin, shortness of breath and reduced exercise tolerance
Impaired cognitive function, difficulty concentrating and irritability
Cold intolerance and reduced immune function
In infants and children, impaired growth and developmental delays
Brittle nails, hair loss and cravings for non-food substances (pica) in severe cases

overview: Zinc is an essential trace element involved in hundreds of enzymatic reactions, protein synthesis, DNA stabilization, immune function and wound healing. It plays structural, catalytic and regulatory roles in numerous biological processes and is required for normal growth and development.
benefits: Supports normal immune function and helps maintain resistance to infections
Required for DNA and protein synthesis and cell division
Contributes to normal wound healing through involvement in tissue repair and collagen synthesis
Essential for normal growth and development during pregnancy, infancy and childhood
Supports normal sense of taste and smell
Acts as a cofactor for antioxidant enzymes, helping protect cells from oxidative damage
sideEffects: High supplemental zinc intake may cause nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps and diarrhea
Chronic excessive intake can interfere with copper absorption, potentially causing copper deficiency and anemia
High doses may impair immune function paradoxically
Zinc can reduce absorption of certain medications, including some antibiotics
deficiencySigns: Impaired immune function and increased susceptibility to infections
Slow wound healing and dermatitis, especially around body openings
Loss of appetite, taste disturbances and smell impairment
Hair loss, diarrhea and weight loss in more severe deficiency
In children, impaired growth and developmental delays
In men, decreased testosterone and reproductive issues in severe deficiency

overview: Copper is an essential trace mineral that plays a role in iron metabolism, antioxidant defense, connective tissue formation and energy production. It acts as a cofactor for many enzymes involved in redox reactions, neurotransmitter synthesis and maintenance of the nervous and cardiovascular systems.
benefits: Required for iron transport and utilization, supporting formation of red blood cells
Plays a role in antioxidant defense through the enzyme superoxide dismutase
Contributes to formation of connective tissue, including collagen and elastin
Supports normal immune function and nervous system development
Helps maintain normal pigment of skin and hair through involvement in melanin production
Required for normal energy metabolism via copper-dependent enzymes
sideEffects: Excessive copper intake from supplements can cause nausea, abdominal pain and vomiting
Chronic high intake may lead to liver damage, oxidative stress and neurological symptoms
People with Wilson’s disease cannot properly eliminate copper and must avoid excess intake
High copper intake can interact with zinc absorption, leading to imbalances
deficiencySigns: Anemia that does not respond to iron supplementation due to impaired iron mobilization
Neutropenia (low white blood cell count), increasing infection risk
Neurological symptoms such as numbness, difficulty walking and sensory disturbances
Bone abnormalities, including osteoporosis and impaired growth in children
Fatigue, hair depigmentation and weakened immune response

overview: Manganese is a trace mineral involved in bone development, metabolism of carbohydrates and amino acids and antioxidant defense. It acts as a cofactor for enzymes such as manganese superoxide dismutase, which protects mitochondria from oxidative damage.
benefits: Supports normal formation and maintenance of bone and cartilage
Acts as a cofactor for enzymes involved in carbohydrate, amino acid and cholesterol metabolism
Important for antioxidant protection via manganese-dependent superoxide dismutase
Contributes to normal wound healing and collagen formation
Supports normal brain and nervous system function
sideEffects: Excess manganese intake from food is rare; toxicity is more common from contaminated water or occupational exposure
High chronic exposure can lead to neurological symptoms resembling Parkinson’s disease (manganism)
Very large supplemental doses may cause cognitive or motor disturbances
deficiencySigns: Bone demineralization and skeletal abnormalities
Skin rashes, impaired wound healing and poor growth
Altered carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
Reproductive issues in severe deficiency (primarily observed in research contexts)
Reduced antioxidant capacity in cells

overview: Selenium is an essential trace mineral incorporated into selenoproteins, which play key roles in antioxidant defense, thyroid hormone metabolism and immune function. It protects cells from oxidative stress and supports normal fertility and cardiovascular health.
benefits: Integral to antioxidant enzymes such as glutathione peroxidases, protecting cells from oxidative damage
Supports normal thyroid hormone production and metabolism
Contributes to immune system function and antiviral defense
May play a role in male fertility through effects on sperm development and motility
Helps maintain DNA integrity and reduces oxidative stress
sideEffects: High selenium intake from supplements can cause selenosis, with symptoms such as hair loss, nail brittleness and garlic-like breath odor
Excessive intake can lead to gastrointestinal upset, skin rash, irritability and neurological abnormalities
Very high doses may increase risk of type 2 diabetes according to some studies, though evidence is mixed
deficiencySigns: Muscle weakness, fatigue and general malaise
Impaired immune function and increased vulnerability to infections
Keshan disease, a form of cardiomyopathy influenced by very low selenium status (rare and region-specific)
Thyroid dysfunction resulting from impaired thyroid hormone metabolism
Reduced antioxidant protection, leading to increased oxidative stress in tissues

overview: Iodine is an essential trace mineral required for the synthesis of thyroid hormones, which regulate metabolism, growth and development. Adequate iodine intake is especially critical during pregnancy and early childhood for proper brain development.
benefits: Required for production of thyroid hormones T3 and T4, which regulate metabolic processes throughout the body
Supports normal growth and development in infants and children
Critical for brain development during fetal and early postnatal life
Contributes to normal energy metabolism
Helps maintain healthy skin through thyroid hormone regulation
sideEffects: Excessive iodine intake can disrupt thyroid function, potentially causing hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism
High intakes may trigger thyroid inflammation or autoimmune thyroid disease in susceptible individuals
Very high doses from supplements or certain seaweeds can be toxic
deficiencySigns: Goiter (enlarged thyroid gland) due to increased TSH stimulation
Hypothyroidism with symptoms such as fatigue, cold intolerance and weight gain
Impaired cognitive function and slowed metabolism
In pregnancy, severe deficiency can cause cretinism, miscarriage and developmental delays
In children, stunted growth and reduced intellectual performance

overview: Fluoride is a trace mineral that strengthens tooth enamel and helps prevent dental caries. It also influences bone mineralization and is naturally present in water, soil and some foods. Fluoride supports mineralization processes in teeth and bones.
benefits: Strengthens tooth enamel and increases resistance to acid-related decay
Helps remineralize areas of early tooth demineralization
Contributes to reduced risk of dental caries in both children and adults
Supports bone mineralization at appropriate intake levels
sideEffects: Excessive fluoride intake during tooth development can cause dental fluorosis, characterized by mottled or discolored enamel
Very high intake over long periods can cause skeletal fluorosis, leading to joint stiffness and bone abnormalities
Acute fluoride toxicity from high-dose ingestion causes nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain
deficiencySigns: Increased risk of dental caries due to less resistant tooth enamel
Reduced remineralization capacity of teeth
Potentially weaker enamel formation during childhood if intake is chronically low

overview: Chromium is an essential trace mineral involved in carbohydrate and lipid metabolism. It enhances the action of insulin and helps regulate blood glucose levels. It is required in very small amounts and found in a variety of foods.
benefits: Enhances insulin signaling and contributes to normal glucose metabolism
Supports normal lipid metabolism and may assist in maintaining healthy cholesterol levels
Contributes to macronutrient metabolism including carbohydrates, fats and proteins
May help improve glucose tolerance in individuals with marginal chromium status
sideEffects: Excessive supplementation with certain chromium forms can cause gastrointestinal discomfort
Very high doses may cause kidney or liver impairment in rare cases
Some poorly regulated supplements have been associated with allergic reactions or skin irritation
deficiencySigns: Impaired glucose tolerance and elevated insulin levels
Peripheral neuropathy and weight loss in severe deficiency (rare in developed countries)
Increased blood lipid abnormalities
Worsened blood sugar regulation in susceptible individuals

overview: Molybdenum is an essential trace mineral that acts as a cofactor for several important enzymes, including those involved in sulfur amino acid metabolism, detoxification of sulfite and breakdown of purines. It is required in very small amounts and is widely distributed in plant foods.
benefits: Acts as a cofactor for enzymes such as sulfite oxidase, xanthine oxidase and aldehyde oxidase
Supports detoxification of sulfites, preventing accumulation of toxic intermediates
Involved in metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids
Contributes to normal breakdown and recycling of purines and other compounds
sideEffects: Excessive molybdenum intake from supplements can cause elevated uric acid levels and gout-like symptoms
Very high doses may interfere with copper metabolism and cause neurological or joint issues
Toxicity from food intake alone is extremely rare due to low typical intakes
deficiencySigns: Deficiency is extremely rare but may cause sulfite sensitivity, neurological abnormalities and metabolic disturbances
Hypotonia, seizures and developmental issues observed in rare genetic defects affecting molybdenum cofactor production
Increased levels of toxic sulfite intermediates in severe deficiency states
